thread.title: 'Quite the party': Table smashed at Abbott's farewell party
thread.title_full: 'Quite the party': Table smashed at Abbott's farewell party | afr.com

author: Primrose Riordan
title: 'Quite the party': Table smashed at Abbott's farewell party
text:
Senator Penny Wong holds up the photo of the damaged marble table during a hearing with the finance and public administration committee at Parliament House on Monday. Alex Ellinghausen Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan Who exactly was atop an Italian marble table when it smashed during a raucous farewell party for former prime minister Tony Abbott is still a mystery.
A Senate estimates hearing, however, revealed new details of the broken table and the accompanying shindig in the dying hours of Mr Abbott's reign.
Cabinet room off limits Parliamentary staff told the hearing they were denied access to the scene of the affair – a cabinet anteroom – until the Friday, three days after the table was broken on the Monday night Mr Abbott lost the Coalition leadership to Malcolm Turnbull.
Tony Abbott's party Rod Clement Parliament's cleaners spotted fragments of the table in other ministers' offices following the event, DPS official John Ryan then said.
"It is understood that the table may have been damaged by a person standing or dancing on it. Anecdotally we have been advised that…more pieces have since been seen in ministerial offices," DPS assistant secretary John Ryan wrote in an email following the event.
Labor Senator Penny Wong lead the questioning, saying the event must have been "quite the party" to have seen the $590 1988 Italian marble table broken into at least two. Tendering photos of the table, officials confirmed some fragments were still missing.
Disco damage? DPS grilled on damage to marble table, during Abbott's party in Min Wing of Parli House after ousted as PM @abcnews pic.twitter.com/LHtrnPlgCf
— Matthew Doran (@MattDoran91) October 19, 2015 Coalition Senators questioned the evidence, saying it was anecdotal, and asked whether the table was weak to begin with.
Senator Cory Bernardi asked if "there any evidence of natural weakness in the stone" and pointed out he had some of his furniture replaced in his office due to structural weaknesses.
Senator Bernardi also suggested it should be referred to as a farewell for loyal staff' rather than a party, and disputed Senator Wong's characterisation of the table as smashed.
"I think it was a damaged table...They could be chips," Senator Bernardi said, accusing Senator Wong of using "inflammatory language".
@workmanalice all good thanks!
— Jamie Briggs (@BriggsJamie) October 12, 2015 Senate President Stephen Parry questioned why cleaners were releasing information in the first place, and said he would investigate whether the cleaners had breached confidentiality rules covering ministerial offices.
DPS said they had received one Quote: for a new table under $1000, and another one "well over that amount".
The day after the spill, Cities Minister Jamie Briggs mysteriously turned up to a party meeting in a wheelchair, which he maintains was a result of an ACL injury while exercising - despite vicious rumours he attended the party.
The hearing also saw DPS give evidence that Attorney-General George Brandis had a bookcase moved to his new office at a cost of $1822, and former defence minister Kevin Andrews took a Chesterfield couch with him to his new office.
The hearing also gave the opportunity for the new Department of Immigration and Border Protection to atone for their Australian Border Force Operation Fortitude fiasco, where it gave the public the impression it would be conducting visa checks in the streets of Melbourne.
Immigration Secretary Pezzulo apologised for the stuff-up, saying it was "regrettable" and "a number of staff have been formally counselled".
ABF Commissioner Roman Quaedvlieg also apologised, saying the media release saying there would be visa checks was "factually wrong", and a "comprehensive review" had been undertaken.
The department also revealed Australia's offshore detention system in Nauru and Manus had cost taxpayers $280 million in the past three months.
